title: 2.4: Multiple Emitters
summary: Learn to create multiple particle systems with different emitters in a single set
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to create multiple particle systems within a single NodeParticleSystemSet. Each system can have its own emitter shape, color, and behavior, allowing you to create complex, layered effects. You'll create a complete setup with two different particle systems - one using a Point emitter and another using a Sphere emitter.
steps: Create the first SystemBlock for the Point Particle System
Create a CreateParticleBlock with initial color (e.g., red) and size
Add a PointShapeBlock to emit particles from a single point
Connect all blocks and add a texture for the first system
Create a second SystemBlock for the Sphere Particle System
Create another CreateParticleBlock with different color (e.g., blue) and size
Add a SphereShapeBlock with a radius input
Add UpdatePositionBlock, UpdateColorBlock, and UpdateSizeBlock for the second system
Connect all blocks and add a texture for the second system
Add both SystemBlocks to the set's systemBlocks array
Observe how both systems run simultaneously, creating layered effects

blocks.name: SystemBlock (Multiple)
blocks.description: You can have multiple SystemBlocks in a single NodeParticleSystemSet. Each SystemBlock represents a separate particle system that runs independently. This allows you to create complex, multi-layered effects.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of each particle system

blocks.name: PointShapeBlock
blocks.description: First emitter: Emits particles from a single point. Used in the first particle system.

blocks.name: SphereShapeBlock
blocks.description: Second emitter: Emits particles from a sphere. Used in the second particle system with a radius input.

properties.name: radius
properties.description: The radius of the sphere emitter

codeCopy: Multiple particle systems in one set allow you to create complex, layered effects. Each SystemBlock runs independently, so you can have different colors, sizes, shapes, and behaviors all happening simultaneously. This is perfect for effects like fire with smoke (two systems), magical auras with particles (multiple systems), or any scenario where you need different particle behaviors in the same scene.
objectives: Understand how to create multiple SystemBlocks in one set
Learn to organize multiple particle systems
Create layered effects with different emitters
Combine different particle behaviors in one scene
Understand when to use multiple systems vs. one complex system

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to add all SystemBlocks to systemBlocks array
commonMistakes.explanation: Each SystemBlock must be added to the set's systemBlocks array. If you create a SystemBlock but don't add it, it won't run.
commonMistakes.solution: Always add all SystemBlocks to set.systemBlocks.push(systemBlock1, systemBlock2, ...). Every SystemBlock you create must be in this array.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using the same variable names for different systems
commonMistakes.explanation: If you reuse variable names (like 'updatePosition' for both systems), the second system will overwrite the first, causing errors.
commonMistakes.solution: Use unique names for each system's blocks: updatePosition1, updatePosition2, or updatePositionPoint, updatePositionSphere.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not understanding that systems run independently
commonMistakes.explanation: Each SystemBlock is completely independent. They don't share particles, properties, or state. This is by design for flexibility.
commonMistakes.solution: Design each system to be self-contained. If you need systems to interact, you'll need to use scene-level logic or combine them into one system.

homework: Create three different particle systems with different colors
Try combining Point, Sphere, and Cone emitters in one set
Create a fire effect with two systems: flames (orange) and smoke (gray)
Experiment with different sizes and behaviors for each system
